      6d
      Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptFyjtbc%253D&md5=42cbb6e1b708cd791929d4e89d328f95

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6e
      Coordination Polymers Containing 1D Channels as Selective Luminescent Probes
      Zhao, Bin; Chen, Xiao-Yan; Cheng, Peng; Liao, Dai-Zheng; Yan, Shi-Ping; Jiang, Zong-Hui
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (47), 15394-15395CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Two 3d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers {[Ln(PDA)3Mn1.5(H2O)3]·3.25H2O}∞ with 1-dimensional channels were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions (H2PDA = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid; Ln = Eu (1); Ln = Tb (2)). The emission intensities of 1 and 2 increased significantly upon addn. of Zn2+, while the introduction of other metal ions caused the intensity to be either unchanged or weakened. The case implies that 1 and 2 may be used as luminescent probes of Zn2+. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1 and 2 were also investigated.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      6f
      Microporous Metal Organic Materials: Promising Candidates as Sorbents for Hydrogen Storage
      Pan, Long; Sander, Michelle B.; Huang, Xiaoying; Li, Jing; Smith, Milton; Bittner, Edward; Bockrath, Bradley; Johnson, J. Karl
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (5), 1308-1309CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Although extensive efforts have been made to improve H storage techniques, there is no viable storage technol. capable of meeting the DOE cost and performance targets. New materials with significantly improved H adsorption capability are needed. Microporous metal coordination materials (MMOMs) are promising sorbents for H adsorption. These materials possess phys. characteristics similar to those of single-walled C nanotubes and they also have a no. of advantages. A novel MMOM structure and its room-temp. H adsorption properties are presented.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXksFClsA%253D%253D&md5=f1b68f3ac25dc59c3ecc58c5300d5c9f

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6g
      Enhancement of H2 adsorption in Li+-exchanged co-ordination framework materials
      Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2008), (46), 6108-6110CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      H2 adsorption in (Me2NH2)[In(L)] is enhanced by exchange of Me2NH2+ for Li+ cations; the Li+-exchanged material displays a lower isosteric heat for H2 adsorption than the parent material, indicating that the increase in H2 capacity is due to an increase in the accessible pore vol. on cation exchange, while the lower adsorption enthalpy is consistent with increased pore size.

      Exceptionally high H2 storage by a metal-organic polyhedral framework
      Yan, Yong; Lin, Xiang; Yang, Sihai; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroeder, Martin
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2009), (9), 1025-1027CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The de-solvated polyhedral framework material, NOTT-112, shows an excess H2 uptake of 7.07% between 35 and 40 bar at 77 K, and a total H2 uptake of 10% at 77 bar and 77 K.

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6i
      High Capacity Hydrogen Adsorption in Cu(II) Tetracarboxylate Framework Materials: The Role of Pore Size, Ligand Functionalization, and Exposed Metal Sites
      Lin, Xiang; Telepeni, Irvin; Blake, Alexander J.; Dailly, Anne; Brown, Craig M.; Simmons, Jason M.; Zoppi, Marco; Walker, Gavin S.; Thomas, K. Mark; Mays, Timothy J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (6), 2159-2171CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Isostructural metal-org. framework polymers [Cu2(L)(H2O)2] (L = tetracarboxylate ligands), denoted NOTT-nnn, were synthesized and characterized. Single crystal x-ray structures confirm the complexes to contain binuclear Cu(II) paddlewheel nodes each bridged by four carboxylate centers to give a NbO-type network of 64·82 topol. These complexes are activated by solvent exchange with acetone coupled to heating cycles under vacuum to afford the desolvated porous materials NOTT-100 to NOTT-109. These incorporate a vacant coordination site at each Cu(II) center and have large pore vols. that contribute to the obsd. high H2 adsorption. Indeed, NOTT-103 at 77 K and 60 bar shows a very high total H2 adsorption of 77.8 mg g-1 equiv. to 7.78% [wt% = (wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material)] or 7.22% [wt% = 100(wt. of adsorbed H2)/(wt. of host material + wt. of adsorbed H2)]. Neutron powder diffraction studies on NOTT-101 reveal three adsorption sites for this material: at the exposed Cu(II) coordination site, at the pocket formed by three {Cu2} paddle wheels, and at the cusp of three Ph rings. Systematic virial anal. of the H2 isotherms suggests that the H2 binding energies at these sites are very similar and the differences are smaller than 1.0 kJ mol-1, although the adsorption enthalpies for H2 at the exposed Cu(II) site are significantly affected by pore metrics. Introducing Me groups or using kinked ligands to create smaller pores can enhance the isosteric heat of adsorption and improve H2 adsorption. However, although increasing the overlap of potential energy fields of pore walls increases the heat of H2 adsorption at low pressure, it may be detrimental to the overall adsorption capacity by reducing the pore vol.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXptlOitQ%253D%253D&md5=cbc9f02158801ff5dacb7df033416d78
      (j) Yang, S., Lin, X., Dailly, A., Blake, A. J., Champness, N. R., Hubberstey, P. and Schröder, M. Chem.—Eur. J. 2009, 15, 4829
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6j
      Enhancement of H2 Adsorption in Coordination Framework Materials by Use of Ligand Curvature
      Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Dailly, Anne; Blake, Alexander J.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2009), 15 (19), 4829-4835, S4829/1-S4829/15CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Enhancement of H2 adsorption was obsd. in coordination framework materials, an example of which is depicted, by the introduction of phenanthrene and 9,10-dihydrophenanthrene groups into porous CuII-carboxylate framework materials of NbO topol. Solvothermal reaction of the ligands H4L110 ((2,7-phenanthrenediyl)diisophthalic acid) and H4L111 ([2,7-(9,10-dihydrophenanthrenediyl)]diisophthalic acid) with Cu(NO3)2·2.5 H2O in a slightly acidified mixt. of DMF/1,4-dioxane/H2O afforded the solvated framework compds. [Cu2(L110)(H2O)2](DMF)7.5(H2O)5 (NOTT-110) and [Cu2(L111)(H2O)2](DMF)7.5(H2O)5 (NOTT-111), resp. Crystal structure detns. confirmed that NOTT-110 and NOTT-111 have the same NbO framework structure, differing only at the 9 and 10 positions of the phenanthrene group. The BET surface areas for desolvated NOTT-110 and NOTT-111 are 2960 and 2930 m2 g-1, resp. Compared with their Ph analogs, introduction of phenanthrene groups to these porous CuII-carboxylate framework materials leads to an enhancement of H2 adsorption. Thus, the H2 isotherms for desolvated NOTT-110 and NOTT-111 confirm 2.64 and 2.56% total H2 uptake, resp., at 1 bar and 78 K. NOTT-110 shows a high total H2 storage capacity of 7.62% at 55 bar and 77 K (8.5% at satn.) with a total volumetric capacity of 46.8 g L-1 at 55 bar and 77 K.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXmtVGrt74%253D&md5=97da3fa9bfd88657d18059efc31b85ac
      (k) Yang, S., Lin, X., Blake, A. J., Walker, G. S., Hubberstey, P., Champness, N. R. and Schröder, M. Nat. Chem., 2009, 1, 487

      6k
      Cation-induced kinetic trapping and enhanced hydrogen adsorption in a modulated anionic metal-organic framework
      Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Walker, Gavin S.; Hubberstey, Peter; Champness, Neil R.; Schroeder, Martin
      Nature Chemistry (2009), 1 (6), 487-493, S487/1-S487/20CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) - microporous materials constructed by bridging metal centers with org. ligands - show promise for applications in storage, which is a key challenge in the development of the hydrogen economy. Their adsorption capacities, however, have remained insufficient for practical applications, and thus strategies to enhance hydrogen-MOF interactions are required. An anionic MOF material built from In(III) centers and tetracarboxylic acid ligands (H4L) in which kinetic trapping behavior - where hydrogen is adsorbed at high pressures but not released immediately on lowering the pressure - is modulated by guest cations. With piperazinium dications in its pores, the framework exhibits hysteretic adsorption. On exchange of these dications with lithium cations, no hysteresis is seen, but instead there is an enhanced adsorption capacity coupled with an increase in the isosteric heat of adsorption. This is rationalized by the different locations of the cations within the pores, detd. with precision by X-ray crystallog.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhtVegsr3E&md5=c8840d0355fddc918e5d399229c4a953

      (a) Horcajada, P., Serre, C., Maurin, G., Ramsahye, N. A., Balas, F., Vallet-Regí, M., Sebban, M., Taulelle, F. and Férey, G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2008, 130, 6774
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7a
      Flexible Porous Metal-Organic Frameworks for a Controlled Drug Delivery
      Horcajada, Patricia; Serre, Christian; Maurin, Guillaume; Ramsahye, Naseem A.; Balas, Francisco; Vallet-Regi, Marila; Sebban, Muriel; Taulelle, Francis; Ferey, Geard
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2008), 130 (21), 6774-6780CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Flexible nanoporous chromium or iron terephthalates (BDC) MIL-53(Cr, Fe) or M(OH)[BDC] have been used as matrixes for the adsorption and in vitro drug delivery of Ibuprofen (or α-p-isobutylphenylpropionic acid). Both MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-53(Fe) solids adsorb around 20 wt % of Ibuprofen (Ibuprofen/dehydrated MIL-53 molar ratio = 0.22(1)), indicating that the amt. of inserted drug does not depend on the metal (Cr, Fe) constitutive of the hybrid framework. Structural and spectroscopic characterizations are provided for the solid filled with Ibuprofen. In each case, the very slow and complete delivery of Ibuprofen was achieved under physiol. conditions after 3 wk with a predictable zero-order kinetics, which highlights the unique properties of flexible hybrid solids for adapting their pore opening to optimize the drug-matrix interactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlsValt7c%253D&md5=1874dd12aa2a23e5c982b8549f5cfae1
      (b) Horcajada, P., Serre, C., Vallet-Regí, M., Sebban, M., Taulelle, F. and Férey, G. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2006, 45, 5974
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7b
      Metal-organic frameworks as efficient materials for drug delivery
      Horcajada, Patricia; Serre, Christian; Vallet-Regi, Maria; Sebban, Muriel; Taulelle, Francis; Ferey, Gerard
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2006), 45 (36), 5974-5978CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The metal carboxylates MIL-100 and MIL-101 (MIL = Materials of Institut Lavoisier) act as porous matrixes for drug-delivery systems using ibuprofen as a model substrate. Very large amts. of the drug could be incorporated, up to an unprecedented capacity of 1.4 g of drug per g of porous solid for MIL-101, and the total release of ibuprofen was achieved under physiol. conditions in 3 (MIL-100) and 6 days (MIL-101).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhtVSrtLfF&md5=b88dbd1aeef6086fe4f1a6f9195d2054

      (a) Kesanli, B. and Lin, W. Coord. Chem. Rev. 2003, 246, 305

      8a
      Chiral porous coordination networks: rational design and applications in enantioselective processes
      Kesanli, Banu; Lin, Wenbin
      Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 305-326CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
      A review is presented which provides a short discussion of recent progress in the synthesis and characterization of homochiral metal-org. coordination networks (MOCNs) and their applications in the areas of asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. Although chiral MOCNs can be constructed from achiral components, the resulting bulk solids tend to be racemic and are thus not useful for enantioselective processes. A couple of examples of homochiral solids built from achiral bridging ligands are presented along with more prevalent homochiral MOCNs built from chiral bridging ligands that are categorized based on their network dimensionality. Preliminary applications of these homochiral solids in asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. are also presented.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpt1Gitrs%253D&md5=fc3129109058ea5a9d7f4716d5aed6b3
      (b) Kiang, Y.-H., Gardner, G. B., Lee, S., Xu, Z. and Lobkovsky, E. B. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1999, 121, 8204
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8b
      Variable Pore Size, Variable Chemical Functionality, and an Example of Reactivity within Porous Phenylacetylene Silver Salts
      Kiang, Y.-H.; Gardner, Geoffrey B.; Lee, Stephen; Xu, Zhengtao; Lobkovsky, Emil B.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1999), 121 (36), 8204-8215CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Studies on mol. variants of the 3-fold sym. 1,3,5-tris(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)benzene crystd. with Ag triflate revealed a nearly invariant pseudohexagonal porous structure type. Modifications involved the attachment of pendant groups to the central arom. ring of the parent mol. Pendant groups include the vinyl group, stilbene, the chiral group myrtanol, and groups with different chem. functionalities such as alcs., ethers, and esters. Modifications also included the addn. of elongated spacer units between the central benzene ring and the peripheral nitrile groups. In these mols. the acetylene bridges of 1,3,5-tris(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)benzene were replaced with diacetylene, ethynylbenzene, and diethynylbenzene type units. Single-crystal refinements for pentyloxy-2,4,6-tris(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)benzene·AgOTf and 1,3,5-tris(4-(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)phenyl)benzene·AgOTf as well as powder data on 12 cryst. phases showed the consistent formation of pseudohexagonal channels, demonstrating that the parent porous architecture is stable both to functional modification of the interior of the channel as well as to enlargement of the pores. Pentoxy-2,4,6-tris(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)benzene·AgOTf refined in the monoclinic space group Am. 1,3,5-Tris(4-(4-ethynylbenzonitrile)phenyl)benzene·AgOTf is triclinic with space group P‾1. These crystals have pseudohexagonal channels resp. 15 and 25 Å in diam. Cell consts. based on powder data are compatible with channel diams. ranging from 10 to 30 Å. The latter channel diams. are among the largest known for org. porous solids. The introduction of the chiral myrtanol unit gave a chiral porous solid. The thermal and chem. stabilities of these phases were studied. The pseudohexagonal structure proved stable to complete solvent loss from the channel. It was found in the case of a host with alc. functionality that an acid anhydride guest, trifluoroacetic anhydride, reacted with the host to form an ester with retention of the porous structure type.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXltlans7w%253D&md5=b81cc5ebc1a2086dc92e6f4349b1ef4d

      (a) Li, H., Eddaoudi, M., O’Keeffe, M. and Yaghi, O. M. Nature 1999, 402, 276
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9a
      Design and synthesis of an exceptionally stable and highly porous metal-organic framework
      Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, M.
      Nature (London) (1999), 402 (6759), 276-279CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
      Open metal-org. frameworks are widely regarded as promising materials for applications in catalysis, sepn., gas storage and mol. recognition. Compared to conventionally used microporous inorg. materials such as zeolites, these org. structures have the potential for more flexible rational design, through control of the architecture and functionalization of the pores. So far, the inability of these open frameworks to support permanent porosity and to avoid collapsing in the absence of guest mols., such as solvents, has hindered further progress in the field. The authors report the synthesis of a metal-org. framework, Zn4O(BDC)3.(DMF)8.(PhCl) (named MOF-5, where BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate), which remains cryst., as evidenced by x-ray single-crystal analyses, and stable when fully desolvated and when heated up to 300°. This synthesis is achieved by borrowing ideas from metal carboxylate cluster chem., where an org. dicarboxylate linker was used in a reaction that gives supertetrahedron clusters when capped with monocarboxylates. The rigid and divergent character of the added linker allows the articulation of the clusters into a three-dimensional framework resulting in a structure with higher apparent surface area and pore vol. than most porous cryst. zeolites. This simple and potentially universal design strategy is currently being pursued in the synthesis of new phases and composites, and for gas-storage applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXnvFSiuro%253D&md5=68f27e20a7e4e15ea2c2f49a2a61e98a
      (b) Rowsell, J. L. C., Millward, A. R., Park, K. S. and Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 5666
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9b
      Hydrogen Sorption in Functionalized Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Millward, Andrew R.; Park, Kyo Sung; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (18), 5666-5667CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Five porous metal-org. frameworks based on linking zinc oxide clusters with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxylate, 4,5,9,10-tetrahydropyrene-2,7-dicarboxylate, 2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, or benzene-1,3,5-tris(4-benzoate) were synthesized in gram-scale quantities to measure their hydrogen uptake properties. Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K show a distinct dependence of uptake on the nature of the link. At 1 atm, the materials sorb between 4.2 and 9.3 mols. of H2 per formula unit. The results imply a trend in hydrogen uptake with the no. of rings in the org. moiety.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Hydrogen Storage in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Eckert, Juergen; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Vodak, David T.; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 300 (5622), 1127-1130CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Metal-org. framework-5 (MOF-5) Zn4O(BDC)3 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a cubic three-dimensional extended porous structure adsorbed hydrogen up to 4.5 wt.% (17.2 hydrogen mols. per formula unit) at 78 K and 1.0 wt.% at room temp. and pressure of 20 bar. Inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy of the rotational transitions of the adsorbed hydrogen mols. indicates two well-defined binding sites (termed I and II), which the authors assoc. with hydrogen binding to zinc and the BDC linker, resp. Preliminary studies on topol. similar isoreticular metal-org. framework-6 and -8 (IRMOF-6 and -8) having cyclobutylbenzene and naphthalene linkers, resp., gave approx. double and quadruple (2.0 wt.%) the uptake found for MOF-5 at room temp. and 10 bar.

      A novel 3-dimensional metal-org. coordination polymer constructed from hollow, spherical, nanometer-sized mol. faceted polyhedra and a flexible tetracarboxylate ligand designed to simultaneously assemble and cross-link these nanoballs in situ was synthesized and structurally characterized.       12a
      In(OH)BDC·0.75BDCH2 (BDC = Benzenedicarboxylate), a Hybrid Inorganic-Organic Vernier Structure
      Anokhina, Ekaterina V.; Vougo-Zanda, Marie; Wang, Xiqu; Jacobson, Allan J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (43), 15000-15001CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The compd. In(OH)BDC·0.75BDCH2 (1, BDC = benzenedicarboxylate) was synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. The structure comprises two distinct sublattices formed by a covalently linked In(OH)BDC lattice and ordered chains of H-bonded H2BDC mols. and can be described as a hybrid inorg. coordination polymer-org. vernier structure. Each InO6 octahedron of the octahedral chain has a length of 3.6 Å along the chain axis, whereas each H2BDC mol. has a length of 9.6 Å along the guest column axis. Therefore, a unit of eight InO6 octahedra of the octahedral chain is just in registry with three H2BDC mols. of the guest column giving a repeat unit of 28.76 Å along the channel axis direction.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhtVOisbbO&md5=57ed8a3f37873b4216447e36f1e4172d
      (b) Pan, L., Parker, B., Huang, X. Y., David, D. H., lee, J. Y. and Li, J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2006, 128, 4180
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12b
      Zn(tbip) (H2tbip = 5-tert-Butyl Isophthalic Acid): A Highly Stable Guest-Free Microporous Metal Organic Framework with Unique Gas Separation Capability
      Pan, Long; Parker, Brett; Huang, Xiaoying; Olson, David H.; Lee, JeongYong; Li, Jing
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (13), 4180-4181CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A novel guest-free microporous metal org. framework (GFMMOF), Zn(tbip) (H2tbip = 5-tert-Bu isophthalic acid) was synthesized and structurally characterized. It contains 1-dimensional close-packed open channels with a pore diam. of 4.5 Å. It demonstrates a remarkable thermal stability, a unique ability to sep. MeOH from di-Me ether or H2O, and is among the microporous MOFs having the highest adsorbed H d. (0.054 g/cm3 at 77 K and 1 atm).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XitlOjtbk%253D&md5=1ffb6ec9c255151b91dd990983052b20
    13. 13
      (a) Kim, J., Chen, B., Reineke, T. M., Li, H., Eddaoudi, M., Moler, D. B., O’Keeffe, M. and Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 8239
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13a
      Assembly of Metal-Organic Frameworks from Large Organic and Inorganic Secondary Building Units: New Examples and Simplifying Principles for Complex Structures
      Kim, Jaheon; Chen, Banglin; Reineke, Theresa M.; Li, Hailian; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Moler, David B.; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (34), 8239-8247CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The secondary building unit (SBU) was identified as a useful tool in the anal. of complex metal-org. frameworks (MOFs). The authors illustrate its applicability to rationalizing MOF crystal structures by anal. of nine new MOFs which were characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. Tetrahedral SBUs in Zn(ADC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-31; H2ADC = acetylenedicarboxylic acid; HTEA = monoprotonated triethylamine), Cd(ATC)·[Cd(H2O)6](H2O)5 (MOF-32; H4ATC = adamantanetetracarboxylic acid), and Zn2(ATB)(H2O)·(H2O)3(DMF)3 (MOF-33; H4ATB = adamantanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into diamond networks, while those of Ni2(ATC)(H2O)4·(H2O)4 (MOF-34) have the structure of the Al network in SrAl2. Frameworks constructed from less sym. tetrahedral SBUs have the Ga network of CaGa2O4 as illustrated by Zn2(ATC)·(EtOH)2(H2O)2 (MOF-35) structure. Squares and tetrahedral SBUs in Zn2(MTB)(H2O)2·(DMF)6(H2O)5 (MOF-36; H4MTB = methanetetrabenzoic acid) are linked into the PtS network, which is the simplest structure type known for the assembly of these shapes. The octahedral SBUs found in Zn2(NDC)3·[(HTEA)(DEF)(ClBz)]2 (MOF-37; H2NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid) form the most common structure for linking octahedral shapes, namely, the B network in CaB6. New structure types for linking triangular and trigonal prismatic SBUs are found in Zn3O(BTC)2·(HTEA)2 (MOF-38; H3BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) and Zn3O(HBTB)2(H2O)·(DMF)0.5(H2O)3 (MOF-39; H3BTB = 1,3,5-benzenetribenzoic acid). The synthesis, crystal structure, and structure anal. using the SBU approach are presented for each MOF.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXls1Okt7w%253D&md5=b62be98fb09b7b7995390315da27c217
      (b) Majumder, A., Gramlich, V., Rosair, G. M., Batten, S. R., Masuda, J. D., El Fallah, M. S., Ribas, J., Sutter, J. P., Desplanches, C. and Mitra, S. Cryst. Growth Des. 2006, 6, 2355
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13b
      Five New Cobalt(II) and Copper(II)-1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate Supramolecular Architectures: Syntheses, Structures, and Magnetic Properties
      Majumder, Arpi; Gramlich, Volker; Rosair, Georgina M.; Batten, Stuart R.; Masuda, Jason D.; El Fallah, M. S.; Ribas, Joan; Sutter, Jean-Pascal; Desplanches, Cedric; Mitra, Samiran
      Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (10), 2355-2368CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      1,2,4,5-Benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4btec) and a combination of N-donor coligands, such as 4-aminopyridine (4-apy), pyrazine (pyz), 2,4,6-tris(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tptz), and 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy) with transition metal ions Co(II) and Cu(II), give rise to five coordination complexes namely, [{Co(H2btec)(H2O)4}·4-apy·(H2O)2]n (1), [{Cu(btec)(4-apy)2}·(4-Hapy)2·(H2O)4]n (2), [{Cu(H3btec)2(pyz)·(H2O)2}·H2O]n (3), [Co(tptz)(H2O)2(H2btec)]·(H2O)2 (4), and [{Co2(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)8}·(btec)·(H2O)2]n (5). All these complexes form supramol. frameworks through ligand-based H bonding interactions. They were characterized by a combination of anal., spectroscopic, and crystallog. methods. These highly cryst. complexes were obtained under different pH conditions at room temp. and the btec binding mode differs in these five complexes. Complex 1 is a 1-dimensional (1D) layered solid consisting of alternating neutral metal-org. coordination polymeric chains, [Co(H2btec)(H2O)4]n, and amines whereas the mol. structure of 2 is made up of alternating layers of anionic [Cu(btec)(4-apy)2]2-n coordination polymers and 4-apy cations (4-Hapy). In both 1 and 2, btec links the metal centers. Complex 3 is composed of zigzag 1-dimensional Cu chains, and complex 4 is a mononuclear Co complex. In both 3 and 4, btec binds as a monodentate ligand. In the crystal structure of 5, btec4- is present unbound in the lattice and linked to 1-dimensional chains of [Co(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)4]2+ through strong H bonding interactions. The magnetic properties of the polymers were studied in the temp. range 300-2 K. The values for the spin coupling const. J are -0.60, -0.50, -0.79, and -5.72 cm-1 for 1-3 and 5, resp., indicative of antiferromagnetic interactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XpsFCrtbk%253D&md5=481daed1c96201d19549a473e63e45a4

      14a
      Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2: A homochiral 3D zinc phosphonate with helical channels
      Shi, Xin; Zhu, Guangshan; Qiu, Shilun; Huang, Kunlin; Yu, Jihong; Xu, Ruren
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (47), 6482-6485CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The prepn. and crystal structure of a homochiral 3D zinc phosphonate, Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2, with helical channels is reported. Three types of channels, right-handed (R) and left-handed (L) helical and achiral (A), alternate along the c axis in the structure of the title compd. The catalytically active groups of the 1-phosphonomethylproline ligands are directed into the channels, thus suggesting applications of this material in asym. catalysis.

      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2008), (3), 359-361CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A biporous three dimensional (3,6)-connected coordination framework is reported which exhibits excellent H2 adsorption at low pressures (≤1 bar) with high H2 adsorption d.

      15a
      Triggered Ligand Release Coupled to Framework Rearrangement: Generating Crystalline Porous Coordination Materials
      Jia, Junhua; Lin, Xiang; Blake, Alexander J.; Champness, Neil R.; Hubberstey, Peter; Shao, Limin; Walker, Gavin; Wilson, Claire; Schroeder, Martin
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (22), 8838-8840CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A robust 3-dimensional porous structure [Ln2(PDC)3(DMF)2]∞ was constructed from lanthanide cations (Ln = Er3+ or Y3+) and the nonlinear anionic bridging ligand, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate (PDC2-) in DMF. The solvated framework polymers {[M2(PDC)3(DMF)2]·n(solv)}∞ (M = Er, Y) undergo a solid-state, crystal-to-crystal reaction upon heating and are converted via loss of both sorbed and coordinated solvent and rearrangement of the framework core to give a desolvated and porous form with retention of structural integrity. This structural transfer is the 1st crystallog. characterized system with lanthanide metal ions. These porous products are effective absorbants for H2, N2, and benzene.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Unprecedented (3,9)-Connected (42.6)3(46.621.89) Net Constructed by Trinuclear Mixed-Valence Cobalt Clusters
      Zhang, Xian-Ming; Zheng, Yan-Zhen; Li, Cui-Rui; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Chen, Xiao-Ming
      Crystal Growth & Design (2007), 7 (5), 980-983CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      A solvothermal reaction of Co2O3, CoSO4, pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid and H2O2 in an aq. MeCN soln. yielded a three-dimensional coordination framework [Co3(OH)(pdc)3]·H2O (1) (pdc = pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate). The mol. structure of complex 1 was detd. using X-ray crystallog. and shows an unprecedented (3,9)-connected (42.6)3(46.621.89) topol. in which hydroxy-centered mixed-valence Co3(OH)(CO2)6 clusters act as nine-connected nodes of a tricapped trigonal prism and pdc groups act as three-connected nodes of trigonal geometry. The magnetic properties of complex 1 were studied and bond valence sum calcns. were performed.

      New Lanthanide Hybrid as Clustered Infinite Nanotunnel with 3D Ln-O-Ln Framework and (3,4)-Connected Net
      Huang, You-Gui; Wu, Ben-Lai; Yuan, Da-Qiang; Xu, Yan-Qing; Jiang, Fei-long; Hong, Mao-Chun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (4), 1171-1176CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      New lanthanide hybrids, [Ln3(μ-OH)4(2,5-pydc)(2,5-Hpydc)3(H2O)4]n (Ln = Gd (1), Dy (2), Er (3), Eu (4), Sm (5), Yb (6), Y (7); 2,5-pydc = pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate), as clustered lanthanide oxide ring tunnels with helical dodecahedral chains and fully 3-dimensional Ln-O-Ln connectivity, were hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by x-ray crystallog. The inorg. skeleton of the hybrid can be specified by the Schlaefli symbol (6210)2 (64102) as a single 3-dimensional (3,4)-connected net. The luminescence properties were studied, and the Dy(III) (2) and Eu(III) (4) complexes exhibited sensitized luminescence in the visible region. Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements of 1-6 showed that the complexes 1-3 are nearly paramagnets, whereas the depopulation of the Stark levels in complexes 4-6 leads to a continuous decrease in μeff when the sample is cooled from 300 to 2 K.

      Synthesis, characterization and photoluminescence properties of two new europium(III) coordination polymers with 3D open framework
      Zhang, Guoqi; Wang, Qian; Qian, Yan; Yang, Guoqiang; Jin, Shi Ma
      Journal of Molecular Structure (2006), 796 (1-3), 187-194CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The 3D open framework coordination polymers [Eu2(fum)3(H2O)4]n·3nH2O (1, fum = fumarate) and [Eu(pdc)(Hpdc)]n (2, pdc = pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate) have been synthesized via hydrothermal procedures. Their mol. structures were detd. by single-crystal X-ray diffraction anal. Polymer 1 adopts a 3D microporous structure filled with disordered free water mols. which interact by hydrogen bonds with terminal water bound to the metal centers. IR spectroscopy, TGA and powder X-ray diffraction anal. revealed that the remarkable dehydration-rehydration process of open-framework 1 is completely reversible. Polymer 2 forms a 3D framework composed of 2D grid-like inorg. sub-networks and pdc ligands as linkers. This solid is highly stable up to 405°C. The solid-state photoluminescence measurements of 1 and 2 exhibited red light-emitting characteristic of europium(III) coordination polymers. Moreover, the anhyd. products were found to be more strongly fluorescent and exhibited longer lifetimes.

      Hydrogen Adsorption in an Interpenetrated Dynamic Metal-Organic Framework
      Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Zapata, Fatima; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Yang, Jun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (15), 5718-5720CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A metal-org. framework Zn(NDC)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5·xG [NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate; 4,4'-Bpe = 4,4'-trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene; G = guest mols.] has been synthesized, structurally characterized, and rationalized to be a two-interpenetrated elongated primitive cubic net. Powder X-ray diffraction and adsorption studies reveal the dynamic feature of the framework, which can take up hydrogen of about 2.0 wt % at 77 K and 40 bar and 0.3 wt % at 298 K and 65 bar.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XmtVygs78%253D&md5=b197758becbf44473a4c5f597817166f

      19b
      Synthesis, X-ray crystal structures, and gas sorption properties of pillared square grid nets based on paddle-wheel motifs: Implications for hydrogen storage in porous materials
      Chun, Hyungphil; Dybtsev, Danil N.; Kim, Hyunuk; Kim, Kimoon
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2005), 11 (12), 3521-3529CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A systematic modulation of org. ligands connecting dinuclear paddle-wheel motifs leads to isomorphous metal-org. porous materials that have a three-dimensional connectivity and interconnected pores. Arom. dicarboxylates such as 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (1,4-bdc), tetramethylterephthalate (tmbdc), 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate (1,4-ndc), tetrafluoroterephthalate (tfbdc), or 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate (2,6-ndc) are linear linkers that form two-dimensional layers, and diamine ligands, 4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (dabco) or 4,4'-dipyridyl (bpy), coordinate at both sides of Zn2 paddle-wheel units to bridge the layers vertically. The resulting open frameworks [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] (1), [Zn2(1,4-bdc)(tmbdc)(dabco)] (2), [Zn2(tmbdc)2(dabco)] (3), [Zn2(1,4-ndc)2(dabco)] (4), [Zn2(tfbdc)2(dabco)] (5), and [Zn2(tmbdc)2(bpy)] (8) possess varying size of pores and free apertures originating from the side groups of the 1,4-bdc derivs. [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(bpy)] (6) and [Zn2(2,6-ndc)2(bpy)] (7) have two- and 3-fold interpenetrating structures, resp. The noninterpenetrating frameworks (1-5 and 8) possess surface areas at 1450-2090 m2g-1 and H sorption capacities of 1.7-2.1% at 78 K and 1 atm. A detailed anal. of the sorption data in conjunction with structural similarities and differences concludes that porous materials with straight channels and large openings do not perform better than those with wavy channels and small openings in terms of H storage through physisorption.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXlt1ygt70%253D&md5=6b32569fb5a054ae4872481379e3463c

      (a) Li, C. J., Hu, S., Li, W., Lam, C. K., Zheng, Y. Z. and Tong, M. L. Eur. J. Inorg. Chem. 2006, 1931
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20a
      Rational design and control of the dimensions of channels in three-dimensional, porous metal-organic frameworks constructed with predesigned hexagonal layers and pillars
      Li, Cui-Jin; Hu, Sheng; Li, Wei; Lam, Chi-Keung; Zheng, Yan-Zhen; Tong, Ming-Liang
      European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2006), (10), 1931-1935CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      New three-dimensional, microporous metal-org. frameworks, [Co3(imda)2(pyz)3]·8H2O, [Co3(imda)2(4,4'-bipy)3]·4,4'-bipy·8H2O and [Co3(imda)3(2,5-bptz)3]·2,5-bptz·9H2O (imdaH3 = 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid; pyz = pyrazine, 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine, 2,5-bptz = 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-thiadiazole), exhibiting reversible H2O adsorption, constructed from hexagonal [Co3(imda)2] layers and N,N'-pillars, in which the dimensions of the channels are rationally adjustable by varying the lengths of pillars, were designed, hydrothermally synthesized, and characterized.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XlsVKjtLs%253D&md5=61cb023ebbf7ccf5ec1db7539e4986bc
      (b) Kitaura, R., Fujimoto, K., Noro, S. I., Kondo, M. and Kitagawa, S. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2002, 41, 133
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20b
      A pillared-layer coordination polymer network displaying hysteretic sorption: [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg)]n (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate; dpyg = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)glycol)
      Kitaura, Ryo; Fujimoto, Kentaro; Noro, Shin-ichiro; Kondo, Mitsuru; Kitagawa, Susumu
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2002), 41 (1), 133-135CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg).8H2O]n (I) (H2pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid; dpyg = 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)glycol) was prepd. by the reaction of C(ClO4)2 with Na2pzdc and dpyg in H2O/EtOH. I is monoclinic, space group P21/c, Z = 2, R = 0.071, Rw = 0.095. In I each Cu(II) is 5-coordinate, residing in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment, surrounded by 3 O atoms from 3 pzdc ligands and 2 N atoms from a dpyg and pzdc ligand. The Cu2(μ-O)2 units are linked together by the pzdc ligands to give a 2-dimensional layer in the bc plane. The dpyg ligand acts as a pillar. The thermal decompn. of I was studied. The adsorption isotherms of anhyd. [Cu2(pzdc)2(dpyg)]n (II) for CH4, H2O and MeOH to exam. the porous properties. II adsorbs MeOH and H2O; and the adsorption isotherms exhibit hysteretic behavior.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (b) Matsuda, R., Kitaura, R., Kitagawa, S., Kubota, Y., Belosludov, R. V., Kobayashi, T. C., Sakamoto, H., Chiba, T., Takata, M., Kawazoe, Y. and Mita, Y. Nature 2005, 436, 238

      21b
      Highly controlled acetylene accommodation in a metal-organic microporous material
      Matsuda, Ryotaro; Kitaura, Ryo; Kitagawa, Susumu; Kubota, Yoshiki; Belosludov, Rodion V.; Kobayashi, Tatsuo C.; Sakamoto, Hirotoshi; Chiba, Takashi; Takata, Masaki; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; Mita, Yoshimi
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2005), 436 (7048), 238-241CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Metal-org. microporous materials (MOMs) have attracted wide scientific attention owing to their unusual structure and properties, as well as com. interest due to their potential applications in storage, sepn. and heterogeneous catalysis. One of the advantages of MOMs compared to other microporous materials, such as activated carbons, is their ability to exhibit a variety of pore surface properties such as hydrophilicity and chirality, as a result of the controlled incorporation of org. functional groups into the pore walls. This capability means that the pore surfaces of MOMs could be designed to adsorb specific mols.; but few design strategies for the adsorption of small mols. have been established so far. Here we report high levels of selective sorption of acetylene mols. as compared to a very similar mol., carbon dioxide, onto the functionalized surface of a MOM. The acetylene mols. are held at a periodic distance from one another by hydrogen bonding between two non-coordinated oxygen atoms in the nanoscale pore wall of the MOM and the two hydrogen atoms of the acetylene mol. This permits the stable storage of acetylene at a d. 200 times the safe compression limit of free acetylene at room temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmtVers7o%253D&md5=33d1004f5e9fc5dff5fe8327ebc502d7

The crystal structure of [Zn2(1,4-bdc)2(dabco)] was detd.

      Microporous Pillared Paddle-Wheel Frameworks Based on Mixed-Ligand Coordination of Zinc Ions
      Ma, Bao-Qing; Mulfort, Karen L.; Hupp, Joseph T.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (14), 4912-4914CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The reaction of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, various dicarboxylic acids and either 4,4'-bipyridine or N,N'-di(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxydiimide produces a family of anisotropic, mixed-ligand, open-framework compds. featuring paddle-wheel-type coordination of Zn(II) pairs in two dimensions and pyridyl ligand pillaring in the 3rd. Despite 2-fold interpenetration, the compds. contain channels of mol. dimensions and several are permanently microporous, displaying high internal surface areas.

      A Catalytically Active, Permanently Microporous MOF with Metalloporphyrin Struts
      Shultz, Abraham M.; Farha, Omar K.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Nguyen, SonBinh T.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (12), 4204-4205CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Through the use of the tetratopic ligand 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H4L) as a key building block, a permanently microporous metal-org. framework with Lewis acidic (porphyrin)Zn struts, ZnPO-MOF, can be made in high yields. The MOF is formulated as [Zn2{Zn(porph)}L] [H2porph = 5,15-dipyrid-4-yl-10,20-bis(pentafluorophenyl)porphyrin]. ZnPO-MOF can efficiently catalyze acyl-transfer reactions primarily by preconcg. the substrates within its pores, in contrast to analogous supramol. systems.

      22f
      Separation of CO2 from CH4 Using Mixed-Ligand Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Bae, Youn-Sang; Mulfort, Karen L.; Frost, Houston; Ryan, Patrick; Punnathanam, Sudeep; Broadbelt, Linda J.; Hupp, Joseph T.; Snurr, Randall Q.
      Langmuir (2008), 24 (16), 8592-8598CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      The adsorption of CO2 and CH4 in a mixed-ligand metal-org. framework (MOF) Zn2(NDC)2(DPNI) [NDC = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylate, DPNI = N,N'-di-(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalene tetracarboxydiimide] was studied using volumetric adsorption measurements and grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations. The MOF was synthesized by 2 routes: 1st at 80° for 2 days with conventional heating, and 2nd at 120° for 1 h using microwave heating. The 2 as-synthesized samples exhibit very similar powder x-ray diffraction patterns, but the evacuated samples show differences in nitrogen uptake. From the single-component CO2 and CH4 isotherms, mixt. adsorption was predicted using the ideal adsorbed soln. theory (IAST). The microwave sample shows a selectivity of ∼30 for CO2 over CH4, which is among the highest selectivities reported for this sepn. The applicability of IAST to this system was demonstrated by performing GCMC simulations for both single-component and mixt. adsorption.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      One Teflon-like channelled nanoporous polymer with a chiral and new uninodal 4-connected net: sorption and catalytic properties

      An Indium Layered MOF as Recyclable Lewis Acid Catalyst
      Gandara, F.; Gomez-Lor, B.; Gutierrez-Puebla, E.; Iglesias, M.; Monge, M. A.; Proserpio, D. M.; Snejko, N.
      Chemistry of Materials (2008), 20 (1), 72-76CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      By using the bent linker 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid) (H2hippb), whose central atom is an sp3 carbon, a new In(III) MOF (metal-org. framework) was obtained. The structure is described as thick layers with the bent geometry of the ligand leading to the formation of square-shaped channels, which run inside the framework layers. This microporous, thermally stable compd. is an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for acetalization of aldehydes. Differences in the catalytic activity when a compd. with empty or filled channels is used demonstrate that the catalytic reactions take place inside the pores.

      23g
      Metal-Organic Frameworks from Dipodal and Tripodal Silicon-Centered Tetrahedral Ligands
      Liu, Zhongqiang; Stern, Charlotte L.; Lambert, Joseph B.
      Organometallics (2009), 28 (1), 84-93CODEN: ORGND7; ISSN:0276-7333. (American Chemical Society)
      Six metal-org. frameworks from org. systems with tetrahedral geometry were prepd. and their crystal structures solved. The org. portions contain different central atoms (M = S, C, Si), a common binding group (4-carboxyphenyl), and a sterically variable series of nonbinding groups (H, =O, CF3, Ph, and tolyl). Five of these systems are dipodal, with two carboxyphenyl groups, and one is tripodal, with three. Dipodal systems with small, nonbinding groups produced two-dimensional, layered structures with medium void percentages. The nonbinding groups are positioned away from the voids. Dipodal systems with large (aryl), nonbinding groups produced three-dimensional networks with larger void percentages. The nonbinding aryl groups are directed into the voids, where they line the surfaces. The single tripodal case produced a two-dimensional, layered structure with a high void percentage. The pore sizes and shapes are tailored by and for the nonbinding groups.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsFSitrfF&md5=8865b61d77ea7c26cd21a3c3e17bba61

      New Ag(I)-Containing Coordination Polymers Generated from Multidentate Schiff-Base Ligands
      Dong, Yu-Bin; Zhao, Xia; Huang, Ru-Qi; Smith, Mark D.; Zur Loye, Hans-Conrad
      Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (18), 5603-5612CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The coordination chem. of the multidentate Schiff-base ligands 2,5-bis(3-methylpyrazinyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (I, R = Me; L5) and 2,5-bis(pyrazinyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (I, R = H; L6) with inorg. Ag(I) salts was investigated. Six new Ag(I)-coordination polymers were prepd. by soln. reactions and fully characterized by IR spectroscopy, elemental anal., TGA, and single-crystal x-ray diffraction. [Ag(L5)]ClO4·0.5CH3OH (1, orthorhombic, space group Fdd2; a 20.0896(11), b 48.224(3), c 7.8432(4) Å, Z = 16), [Ag(L5)]PF6·0.5CH3OH (2, orthorhombic, space group Fdd2; a 20.7255(11), b 46.166(2), c 8.4332(4) Å, Z = 16), [Ag(L5)]SbF6·0.5CH3OH (3, orthorhombic, Fdd2; a 21.5481(11), b 45.196(2), c 8.7331(4) Å, Z = 16), and [Ag(L5)](BF4)·0.5CH3OH (4, orthorhombic, Fdd2; a 19.8897(11), b 48.358(3), c 7.7491(5) Å, Z = 16) were obtained by combination of L5 with AgClO4·xH2O, AgPF6, AgSbF6, and AgBF4, resp., in a methylene chloride/methanol mixed solvent system. Compds. 1-4 are isostructural and feature noninterpenetrating three-dimensional zeolite-like networks. [Ag4(L6)4](PF6)4·CHCl3 (5, tetragonal, space group P‾4c2; a 16.1067(3), b 16.1067(3), c 14.4935(5) Å, Z = 2) was generated from the reaction of L6 with AgPF6 in a chloroform/ethanol mixed solvent system. It forms with a unique 1-dimensional nanometer-tube that can be considered a new polymeric motif based on the {AgN5} coordination sphere. The tubes are square with crystallog. dimensions of 10.3 × 10.0 Å. The tubes are further linked together through weak interpolymer C-H···F hydrogen bonding interactions into a novel H-bonded three-dimensional network contg. square tubes, in which uncoordinated PF6- counterions and chloroform guest mols. are located. Compd. 6 ([Ag(μ-C6H6N2O)](SO3CF3), monoclinic, space group P21/c; a 12.3435(6), b 20.3548(10), c 9.0861(5) Å, Z = 8) was obtained by combination of AgSO3CF3 and L6 in a methylene chloride/benzene mixed solvent system. In 6, 2-acetylpyrazine, which was generated from the hydrolysis reaction of L6 in the presence of CF3SO3- and a small quantity of water in solvent, chelates the Ag(I) centers through the carbonyl O-donor, and the vicinal pyrazine N-donor, also, uses the para-N atoms to link other Ag(I) centers into 1-dimensional zigzag chains. The triflate anions link the chains into a three-dimensional network by somewhat long Ag···O contacts. The luminescent properties of 1-5 are also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      28
      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e

      (a) Eddaoudi, M., Li, H. and Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2000, 122, 1391
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29a
      Highly porous and stable metal-organic frameworks. Structure design and sorption properties
      Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Li, Hailian; Yaghi, O. M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2000), 122 (7), 1391-1397CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Gas sorption isotherm measurements performed on the evacuated derivs. of 4 porous metal-org. frameworks (MOF-n), Zn(BDC).(DMF)(H2O) (DMF = N,N'-dimethylformamide, BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) (MOF-2), Zn3(BDC)3.6CH3OH (MOF-3), Zn2(BTC)NO3.(C2H5OH)5H2O (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) (MOF-4), and Zn4O(BDC)3.(DMF)8C6H5Cl (MOF-5), reveal type I isotherms for n = 2, 3, and 5, which is evidence of microporous and accessible channels having high structural integrity and organization. Although gas sorption into MOF-4 was not obsd., careful examn. of its ethanol sorption isotherms at 22 and 32° point to the presence of coordinatively unsatd. Zn centers within its pores, which upon ethanol sorption undergo coordination transitions from 3- to 4-, 4- to 5-, and 5- to 6-coordination. MOF-n materials were produced by building the extended analogs of mol. metal carboxylate clusters, a strategy that has allowed the realization of the most porous and thermally stable framework yet reported: the evacuated form of MOF-5 is esp. stable in air at 300° and has a free pore vol. representing 55-60% of its crystal as detd. by gas sorption and single-crystal diffraction studies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXotl2jsg%253D%253D&md5=bf52caa3fb6a6e160f205f938db8b3a7
      (b) Eddaoudi, M., Kim, J., Wachter, J. B., Chae, H. K., O’Keeffe, M. and Yaghi, O. M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 4368

      29b
      Porous Metal-Organic Polyhedra: 25 Å Cuboctahedron Constructed from 12 Cu2(CO2)4 Paddle-Wheel Building Blocks
      Eddaoudi, M.; Kim, Jaheon; Wachter, J. B.; Chae, H. K.; O'Keeffe, M.; Yaghi, O. M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2001), 123 (18), 4368-4369CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A porous metal-org. polyhedron Cu24(m-BDC)24(DMF)14(H2O)10·(H2O)50(DMF)6(C2H5OH)6 (I), hereafter termed a-MOP-1 (a = anorthic = triclinic) which is constructed from 12 paddle-wheel units bridged by m-BDC (m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate) to give a large metal-carboxylate polyhedron. I is triclinic, using the centrosym. space group P‾1 with Z = 1 and a 23.5283(15), b 24.3224(16), c 25.0401(16) Å, α 61.479(1), β 82.864(1), γ 75.298(1)°; final full matrix least -squares refinement on F2 converged to R1 = 0.1710 (I > 2σ(I)) and wR2 = 0.4618 (all data) with GOF = 1.371. The simplest way to view the structure is by considering its relationship to the cuboctahedron, where each square and link have been replaced by the paddle-wheel (square SBU) and the m-BDC (two-connector) units, resp., to give an expanded-augmented cuboctahedron (truncated cuboctahedron, 4.6.8 Archimedean polyhedron). This arrangement results in a porous polyhedron having 8 triangular and 6 square crevices that are 8 and 12 Å across, resp. These open into an internal spherical cavity having an av. diam. of 15 Å and a vol. of 1766 Å3. Each paddle-wheel unit of the Cu-O-C polyhedron has two terminal ligands: one pointing into the internal cavity toward the center of the polyhedron while the other is bound to the copper center outside pointing away from the outside surface of the polyhedron. Thus, the paddle-wheel units have a total of 24 terminal DMF and water ligands. Cu24(m-BDC)24(H2O)24.42H2O was also isolated and its crystal structure is cubic, space group Im‾3m, R1 = 0.1004, wR2 = 0.3427.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXis1ylurs%253D&md5=bb3bd857b4c1b05a1ac8fbebf68a4ea6
      (c) Wang, R., Han, L., Jiang, F., Zhou, Y., Yuan, D. and Hong, M. Cryst. Growth Des. 2005, 5, 129
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29c
      Three Novel Cadmium(II) Complexes from Different Conformational 1,1'-Biphenyl-3,3'-dicarboxylate
      Wang, Ruihu; Han, Lei; Jiang, Feilong; Zhou, Youfu; Yuan, Daqiang; Hong, Maochun
      Crystal Growth & Design (2005), 5 (1), 129-135CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Three novel Cd(II) coordination polymers, [Cd2(4,4'-bipy)(3,3'-bpda)2]n (1), [Cd4(bpe)3(μ-H2O)2(3,3'-bpda)4]n (2), and [Cd2(3,3'-bpda)2]n (3), were hydrothermally synthesized by 1,1'-biphenyl-3,3'-dicarboxylate (3,3'-bpda) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with exo-bidentate pyridyl-contg. ligands, 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy), 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe), and 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (dpp), resp. X-ray crystal structural analyses reveal that the three polymers possess different novel structural motifs derived from different conformations of the 3,3'-bpda ligand. In 1, 3,3'-bpda in a trans conformation links paddle wheel dimeric Cd-tetracarboxylate building units resulting in a two-dimensional layer, which is further bridged by 4,4'-bipy generating a three-dimensional framework with a 3-fold interpenetrating structure. 3,3'-Bpda in 2 has a cis conformation and bridges among six-coordinated and seven-coordinated CdII centers forming a tetranuclear Cd unit, which is further connected by bpe producing a two-dimensional layer. The larger cavities in a layer of 2 result in mutually perpendicular interpenetrating two-dimensional layers. Complex 3 is an unprecedented three-dimensional polymer consisting of double chains formed from two different trans bridging 3,3'-bpda and five-coordinated Cd(II) centers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXns12rtro%253D&md5=1abc1be34005ec16ef2b2708835adbe2
      (d) Guo, X., Zhu, G., Fang, Q., Xue, M., Tian, G., Sun, J., Li, X. and Qiu, S. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 3850
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29d
      Synthesis, Structure and Luminescent Properties of Rare Earth Coordination Polymers Constructed from Paddle-Wheel Building Blocks
      Guo, Xiaodan; Zhu, Guangshan; Fang, Qianrong; Xue, Ming; Tian, Ge; Sun, Jinyu; Li, Xiaotian; Qiu, Shilun
      Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (11), 3850-3855CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      Three-dimensional (3D) novel coordination polymers M(bpdc)1.5(H2O)·0.5DMF (M = Tb (1), Ho (2), Er (3), or Y (4)) were synthesized by reaction of the rare earth ions (M3+) with 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid (H2bpdc) in a mixed soln. of DMF and EtOH. They possess the same 3-dimensional architectures and crystallize in monoclinic space group C2/c. Two seven-coordinated metal centers and four dimonodentate bpdc groups construct a paddle-wheel building block. These building blocks connect with two carboxyl groups to lead to a 1-dimensional inorg. chain, ---M-O-C-O-M..., along the [001] direction. The inorg. chains are linked with two biphenyl groups to form 25.15 Å × 17.09 Å rhombic channels along the c axis without interpenetration. These complexes exhibit strong fluorescence in the visible region, and complex 3 shows Er3+ characteristic emission at 1450-1650 nm at room temp. These complexes could be anticipated as potential fluorescent probes and an IR-emitter, resp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjsFCqsr4%253D&md5=74ec53c49bb30321b591fde41d30d8dd
      (e) Chui, S. S.-Y., Lo, S. M.-F., Charmant, J. P. H., Orpen, A. G. and Williams, I. D. Science 1999, 283, 1148
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29e
      A chemically functionalizable nanoporous material [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n
      Chui, Stephen S.-Y.; Lo, Samuel M.-F.; Charmant, Jonathan P. H.; Orpen, A. Guy; Williams, Ian D.
      Science (Washington, D. C.) (1999), 283 (5405), 1148-1150CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      Although zeolites and related materials combine nanoporosity with high thermal stability, they are difficult to modify or derivatize in a systematic way. A highly porous metal coordination polymer [Cu3(TMA)2(H2O)3]n (TMA is benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylate) was formed in 80% yield. It has interconnected [Cu2(O2CR)4] units (R is an arom. ring), which create a three-dimensional system of channels with a pore size of 1 nm and an accessible porosity of ∼40% in the solid. Unlike zeolites, the channel linings can be chem. functionalized; for example, the aqua ligands can be replaced by pyridines. TGA and high-temp. single-crystal diffractometry indicate that the framework is stable up to 240°.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXhsFeitLc%253D&md5=8f6f372b015fa0e2bbb7e8bfd316b663
      (f) Vos, T. E., Liao, Y., Shum, W. W., Her, J.-H., Stephen, P. W., Reiff, W. M. and Miller, J. S. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2004, 126, 11630
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      29f
      Diruthenium Tetraacetate Monocation, [RuII/III2(O2CMe)4]+, Building Blocks for 3-D Molecule-Based Magnets
      Vos, Thomas E.; Liao, Yi; Shum, William W.; Her, Jae-Hyuk; Stephens, Peter W.; Reiff, William M.; Miller, Joel S.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (37), 11630-11639CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Diruthenium tetracarboxylates monocations were used as building blocks for cubic 3-dimensional network structured mol.-based magnets. [RuII/III2(O2CMe)4]3[MIII(CN)6] [M = Cr (1a), Fe (2), Co (3)] were prepd. in aq. soln. Powder x-ray diffraction indicates that they have bcc. structures (space group Im‾3m, a 13.34, 13.30, and 13.10 Å for 1a, 2, and 3, resp.), which was confirmed for 1a by Reitveld anal. of the synchrotron powder data [a 13.3756(5) Å]. [Ru2(O2CMe)4]3[MIII(CN)6]·xMeCN [M = Cr, x = 1.8 (1b); M = Mn, x = 3.3(4)] were prepd. from MeCN. The magnetic ordering of 1a (33 K), 1b (34.5 K), 2 (2.1 K), and 4 (9.6 K) was detd. from the temp. dependencies of the in-phase (χ') a.c. (a.c.) susceptibility. The field dependence of the magnetization, M(H), at 2 K for 1a showed an unusual constricted hysteresis loop with a coercive field, Hcr, of 470 Oe while the M(H) data for 1b, 2, and 4 showed a normal hysteresis loop with a coercive field of 1670, 10, and 990 Oe, resp. The 57Fe Mossbauer spectrum of 2 is consistent with the presence of low spin FeIII (δ = -0.05 mm/s; ΔE = 0.33 mm/s) at room temp., and the onset of 3-dimensional magnetic ordering at lower temp. (<2 K). The effects of MIII in [MIII(CN)6]3-, and the large zero-field splitting (D) of diruthenium tetracarboxylates are discussed. The increasing crit. temps. Tc, with increasing S could not be accounted for by mean field models without significantly different J values for 1a, 4, and 2. By fitting the Tc data with mean field models [H = -2JSRu.SM - μB(gRuSRu + gMSM)H], J/kB are 4.46, 1.90, and 0.70 K for 1a, 4, and 2, resp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXmvFSqsr8%253D&md5=7de161fa43f99ef6f83ca442f2d0a4c6
      (g) Han, L., Zhou, Y., Zhao, W.-N., Li, X. and Liang, Y.-X. Cryst. Growth Des. 2009, 9, 660

      Assembly of Metal-Organic Frameworks with Helical Layer: From 2D Parallel Interpenetrated Layer to 3D Self-Penetrating Network
      Han, Lei; Zhou, Yan; Zhao, Wen-Na; Li, Xing; Liang, Yun-Xiao
      Crystal Growth & Design (2009), 9 (2), 660-662CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel Co(II)-org. frameworks with helical structures, [Co(hfipbb)(py)]n (1) and {[Co4(OH)(H2O)(hfipbb)3(Hhfipbb)(bpp)2]·H2O}n (2) (H2hfipbb = 4,4'-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)bis(benzoic acid), py = pyridine, bpp = 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane), have been assembled from flexible bent ligands. Complex 1 displays a 2-fold parallel interpenetrated layer network with one-dimensional double helical channels, while 2 exhibits a three-dimensional pillared helical-layer open framework with six-connected self-penetrating topol. based on a mixed dinuclear paddle-wheel cluster and tetranuclear [Co4(μ3-OH)2(μ2-OH2)2] steplike cluster.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhsFChsLvJ&md5=1a8f84afc41c6a9bd9549823580445c9

      30a
      Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
      Spek, A. L.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
      The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2
      (b) Sluis, P.v.d. and Spek, A. L. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A 1990, 46, 194
      [Crossref], Google Scholar

      31
      Hydrogen Adsorption on Functionalized Nanoporous Activated Carbons
      Zhao, X. B.; Xiao, B.; Fletcher, A. J.; Thomas, K. M.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2005), 109 (18), 8880-8888CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1520-6106. (American Chemical Society)
      There is considerable interest in hydrogen adsorption on carbon nanotubes and porous carbons as a method of storage for transport and related energy applications. This investigation has involved a systematic investigation of the role of functional groups and porous structure characteristics in detg. the hydrogen adsorption characteristics of porous carbons. Suites of carbons were prepd. with a wide range of nitrogen and oxygen contents and types of functional groups to investigate their effect on hydrogen adsorption. The porous structures of the carbons were characterized by nitrogen (77 K) and carbon dioxide (273 K) adsorption methods. Hydrogen adsorption isotherms were studied at 77 K and pressure up to 100 kPa. All the isotherms were Type I in the IUPAC classification scheme. Hydrogen isobars indicated that the adsorption of hydrogen is very temp. dependent with little or no hydrogen adsorption above 195 K. The isosteric enthalpies of adsorption at zero surface coverage were obtained using a virial equation, while the values at various surface coverages were obtained from the van't Hoff isochore. The values were in the range 3.9-5.2 kJ mol-1 for the carbons studied. The thermodn. of the adsorption process are discussed in relation to temp. limitations for hydrogen storage applications. The max. amts. of hydrogen adsorbed correlated with the micropore vol. obtained from extrapolation of the Dubinin-Radushkevich equation for carbon dioxide adsorption. Functional groups have a small detrimental effect on hydrogen adsorption, and this is related to decreased adsorbate-adsorbent and increased adsorbate-adsorbate interactions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjt1Sksbo%253D&md5=0339581fa3db0f5d5d1d2efd6a14b29f

      Discovery, Synthesis, and Characterization of an Isomeric Coordination Polymer with Pillared Kagome Net Topology
      Chun, Hyungphil; Moon, Jumi
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (11), 4371-4373CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A topol. isomer based on Zn2 paddlewheel 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), and diamine (Dabco) ligands was synthesized by solvothermal methods after careful modulation of the reaction conditions. The new framework, [Zn2(bdc)2(dabco)], was characterized by a pillared Kagome net topol. and possesses a sustainable pore structure with high surface area (∼2400 m2/g) and large hexagonal channels (∼15 Å).
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A triply interpenetrated microporous metal-organic framework for selective sorption of gas molecules
      Chen, Banglin; Ma, Shengqian; Hurtado, Eric J.; Lobkovsky, Emil B.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Inorganic Chemistry (2007), 46 (21), 8490-8492CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      A microporous metal-org. framework Zn(ADC)(4,4'-Bpe)0.5.xG [1; ADC = 4,4'-azobenzenedicarboxylate, 4,4'-Bpe = trans-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, G = 2.5DMF.0.5H2O] with a triply interpenetrative primitive cubic net was synthesized and characterized. With pores of ∼3.4 × 3.4 Å, the activated 1a (no solvent) exhibits highly selective sorption behavior toward H2/N2, H2/CO, and CO2/CH4.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVegsr%252FF&md5=5c0358d8de80bceb28329e0ec9d1be01

      33a
      Design of Novel Bilayer Compounds of the CPO-8 Type Containing 1D Channels
      Kongshaug, Kjell Ove; Fjellvg, Helmer
      Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (6), 2424-2429CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The reaction between Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 5-aminoisophthalic acid (aip) in a mixt. of diethylformamide (DEF) and ethanol resulted in [Zn(C8H5NO4)(DEF)]n. This compd. is composed of infinite 2D layers with tetrahedral Zn atoms and aip ligands in a triangular topol. The DEF mols. are bonded to Zn and within each layer the DEF mols. are oriented in the same direction while in the subsequent layer the DEF mols. are oriented in the opposite direction. By introduction of the pillaring ligands 4,4-bipyridine (BPY), 1,2-di-4-pyridylethylene (DPE), 1,2-di-4-pyridylethane (DPA), and 1,3-di-4-pyridylpropane (DPP) into mixts. of N,N'-dimethylformamide and water with Zn(NO3)2 and aip we have successfully synthesized a series of related pillared bilayer compds. with the same common triangular Zn(aip) layer structural motif as that obsd. in [Zn(C8H5NO4)(DEF)]n. The compds. are [Zn(C8H5NO4)(BPY)0.5]n·3nH2O, [Zn(C8H5NO4)(DPE)0.5]n·2.5nH2O, [Zn(C8H5NO4)(DPA)0.5]n·2.5nH2O and [Zn(C8H5NO4)(DPP)0.5]n·3nH2O. In all cases the pillars create spaces inside the bilayers that result in 1D channels running along the [010] directions with dimensions of 3.5 × 6.7 Å2. These channels contain water mols. that can be removed on heating to 150 °C resulting in porous structures. The crystal structures of these porous high-temp. variants have been detd. on the basis of powder X-ray diffraction data. All of the compds. show preferential adsorption of H2 over N2 at 77 K.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xht1yhsb8%253D&md5=80aa0fe5757b0984ed430cb359fa2de3
      (b) Cabeza, A., Gómez-Alάntara, M. D. M., Olivera-Pastor, P., Sobrados, I., Sanz, J., Xiao, B., Morris, R. E., Clearfield, A. and Aranda, M. A.G. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2008, 114, 322
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33b
      From non-porous crystalline to amorphous microporous metal(IV) bisphosphonates
      Cabeza, Aurelio; Gomez-Alcantara, Maria del Mar; Olivera-Pastor, Pascual; Sobrados, Isabel; Sanz, Jesu; Xiao, Bo; Morris, Russell E.; Clearfield, Abraham; Aranda, Miguel A. G.
      Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2008), 114 (1-3), 322-336CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier)
      Porous layered hybrid materials were prepd. by the reaction of organo-bisphosphonate ligands, 4-(4'-phosphonophenoxy)phenylphosphonic, 4,4'-biphenylenbisphosphonic and phenylphosphonic acids, with metal(IV) cations (Zr and Sn). Cryst. Zr(IV) and Sn(IV) layered bisphosphonates were also prepd., which were nonporous. The amorphous M(IV) bisphosphonates showed variable compns. and textural properties ranging from mainly mesoporous to highly microporous solids with BET surface areas varying from 300 to 480 m2 g-1, micropore vols. ranging 0.10-0.20 cm3/g, and narrow porous size distributions for some materials. N2 isotherms suggest that Sn(IV) derivs. show a comparatively higher micropore contribution than the Zr(IV) analogous at least for the ether-bisphosphonate hybrids. Sn(IV) bisphosphonates exhibit high microporosities without the need of using harmful DMSO as solvent. If ether-bisphosphonic acid is partially replaced by less expensive phenylphosphonic ligand, porous products are also obtained. 31P and 17F MASNMR and XPS data revealed hydrogen-phosphonate groups and small (F-, Cl- and OH-) anions, which act as spacer ligands within the inorg. layers, in these hybrid materials. The complexity of the inorg. layers is higher for the Sn(IV) bisphosphonates likely due to the larger amt. of small bridging anions including fluorides. Probably the presence of these small inorg. ligands may be a key factor influencing both, the interaction of the inorg. layer with the bisphosphonate groups, which bridge the inorg. layers, and the generation of internal voids within a given inorg. layer. Preliminary studies of gases adsorption (H2 and NO) were carried out for selected Sn(IV) bisphosphonates. The H2 adsorption capacity at 77 K and 1 bar was low, 0.26%, but the NO adsorption capacity at ∼1 bar and 298 K was relatively high, 4.2%. Also, the hysteresis in the NO isotherms is indicative of partial strong irreversible adsorption of NO.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXns1ahurc%253D&md5=d58f54e6489b82b897da044b67964724
